channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: In First Economic Review, Italy and Spain Get Warnings
item.description: The top European economics official said the two countries risked missing important debt and deficit targets.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Youth Sues Over Alleged Police Torture
item.description: After Yang Zhong, 16, was taken away by police on suspicion of “spreading online rumors,” he says they tortured him. Now he’s suing for 7 renminbi, one for each day of detention, and an apology.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Yang Zhong is seeking an apology from the local police.

item.title: Chemical Arms Monitor Debates Syrian Plan to Destroy Weapons
item.description: Other nations that might play a role in the plan displayed continued reluctance to allow their territory to be used for the destruction of around 1,300 tons of chemical weapons.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Red Cross Workers in Philippines Pull Bodies Before Turning to Rescues
item.description: Volunteers from the Philippine Red Cross searched for bodies in Tacloban, highlighting the mundane tasks many aid workers face as thousands of residents remain hungry and homeless.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A corpse was carried on Thursday to a mass grave in Tacloban, the city of 220,000 that was flattened by the storm that made landfall a week ago. The number of dead still remains uncertain.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Talks Up Economic Reform
item.description: Shares in Shanghai and Hong Kong rose as a Communist Party official said that the broad policy statements issued this week would yield significant change.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: In France, New Tech Academy Defies Conventional Wisdom
item.description: The founding of “42,” which offers computer programming classes but no state-sanctioned degree, is seen by some educators as an affront to tradition.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: India Ink: ‘Hearts Throbbed, Minds Wavered’ as Tendulkar Began Final Match
item.description: The final five-day test match for Sachin Tendulkar prompted a full meltdown of ecstatic prose, as scribes all over the country tried to capture the final bittersweet moments of the cricket giant’s career.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Schoolchildren holding posters of cricketer Sachin Tendulkar at an event to honor him in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi, in ‘Godfather’ Mold, Looks Assertive and Even Imperial
item.description: One year after taking leadership of the Communist Party, Xi Jinping is looking like an assertive president who sits well above his six colleagues on the Politburo Standing Committee, a sharp contrast to his predecessor, Hu Jintao.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, the Chinese president, recently cemented his power base at a gathering of Chinese leaders.

item.title: Saul Kagan, Who Won Holocaust Restitution, Is Dead at 91
item.description: Mr. Kagan was the founding director of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany, which sought reparations for the Nazi genocide against European Jews.
item.category: Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: Saul Kagan, right, in 1958, with Nahum Goldmann, the first president of a Jewish group created to seek reparations for victims of the Nazis.

item.title: His Roots in Italy, de Blasio Now Has Fans There
item.description: Bill de Blasio has become something of a sensation in Italy, but the country has long been a singular force in shaping his life, and an identity he claimed as his family was falling apart.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: A figurine of Bill de Blasio, New York’s mayor-elect, in Italy.

item.title: Asia Rivalries Play Role in Aid to the Philippines
item.description: The foreign aid for the survivors of Typhoon Haiyan is shaping up to be a monumental show of international largess — and a dose of one-upmanship directed at China.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: A shipment of food unloaded from an American military helicopter in Guiuan, Philippines, on Thursday.

item.title: Not Even Marcos Family Is Spared Residents’ Ire
item.description: Some of the blame for the slow relief efforts after Typhoon Haiyan is falling on Imelda Marcos and her family, who have long been revered in Tacloban, the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: The staff quarters at a mansion in Tacloban that once held Imelda Marcos’s shoe collection.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Would You Like Fries With Those Spicy Pork McBites?
item.description: The new pork treat is in line with the overall global strategy of Western chains tailoring their menus to local tastes.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: Ravaged by Typhoon, Philippines Faces Threat of Serious Diseases
item.description: Illnesses that thrive in tropical, fetid environments, where sewage and water supplies intermingle, could form what doctors fear is the disaster’s second wave.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Turkey Moves to Silence Dissenters, but With One Eye on Its Image Abroad
item.description: Turkey has mounted a balancing act, analysts say, of cracking down on critics of the government, but not so hard as to damage the country’s image abroad.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Demonstrators waved Turkish flags and shouted slogans in Gezi Park in Istanbul in June, as protests were spreading.

item.title: Obama Calls for Patience in Iran Talks
item.description: President Obama argued against a plan to impose new sanctions against Iran while negotiators sought a six-month agreement to freeze Tehran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: U.S. Dancer Quits the Bolshoi, Complaining of Bribery
item.description: Joy Womack, an American dancer at the prestigious Bolshoi Ballet, says she was told she would have to pay a $10,000 bribe to get a solo role.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joy Womack in 2010 as an American student at the academy that feeds the Bolshoi.

item.title: Golan Heights Journal: On a Mission Within Earshot of a War, Armed With Paint
item.description: A group of graffiti painters from several countries gathered in the disputed region to add color to a building’s ruins.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dmitrij Proskein, who calls himself Chemis, with one of his works on a Golan Heights wall.

item.title: C.I.A. Collecting Data on International Money Transfers, Officials Say
item.description: The agency is secretly collecting bulk records of international money transfers, under the same law that the National Security Agency uses for its phone record database, according to government officials.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Government in Egypt Eases Restrictions
item.description: The interim government lifts a state of emergency and a nighttime curfew after three months — an indication of its confidence in its control of the country.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: In Venezuela, Campaign Takes the Form of a Fire Sale
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro is trying to quell frustration with the economy ahead of municipal elections by forcing retailers to slash prices.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Cameroon: French Priest Kidnapped
item.description: There has been no claim of responsibility, but the Nigerian Islamist militant groups Boko Haram and Ansaru are known to operate in the region, near the border with Nigeria.
item.category: Ansaru (Vanguard for the Protection of Muslims in Black Africa)
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Last Shipment of Nuclear Fuel From Russian Bombs Heads to U.S.
item.description: Dignitaries in St. Petersburg, Russia, commemorated the end of the Megatons to Megawatts program as uranium made from warhead cores left for Baltimore.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Palestinian Family’s Home Is Set on Fire
item.description: Hebrew graffiti outside suggested that the arson was an act of revenge for the fatal stabbing of an Israeli soldier by a Palestinian teenager the day before.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Hundreds Arrested in Child Pornography Investigation
item.description: A three-year investigation into child pornography has led to the rescue of 386 children around the world and the arrest of 348 people, the Toronto police said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
